Award.AwardTitle: Key Parameter for the Mass and Energy Transfer at the Magnetopause Determined from Cusp Structures
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will examine the processes that are involved with magnetic reconnection at the dayside magnetopause of the Earth. It will determine the relative occurrence of anti-parallel reconnection versus component reconnection as a function of the parameters of the solar wind that control the interaction. It will also examine the transition from one mode of reconnection to the other and will determine under what conditions magnetic reconnection becomes quasi-continuous and under what conditions it becomes intermittent. The project will analyze the nature of structures in the magnetic cusp using the low-velocity cutoff method to determine the location of the reconnection site. The data to be used in this study come from a number of space missions, in particular the European Space Agency's Cluster Mission and the NASA THEMIS mission.

Magnetic reconnection at the magnetopuse is the dominant mechanism by which plasma mass and energy is transported from the solar wind into the magnetopause and eventually to the upper atmosphere. In order to provide quantitative predictions about the mass and energy transfer, several paramters need to be known as a function of the solar wind conditions. Among these parameters is the relative occurrence of anit-parallel reconnection versus component reconnection. In addition to the senior personnel involved with this research, during the summer months high school science teachers will participate in the project through the Industry Initiatives for Science and Math Education (IISME) program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Local noon studies:

The first two science questions of this effort (Q1: What is the relative occurrence of anti-parallel versus component reconnection at the dayside magnetopause?; Q2: What governs the transition between the anti-parallel and component reconnection scenarios?) have been studied by examining the magnetopause area around local noon, where the differences between the physical location corresponding to anti-parallel and to component reconnection would be maximized. In previous studies the solar wind magnetic field (IMF) conditions were used to distinguish and establish conditions for which of either anti-parallel reconnection locations or component reconnection locations would occur at the Earth's magnetopause. While dominant IMF By conditions seem to favor component reconnection locations, dominant IMF Bx or Bz conditions suggest that reconnection occurs at the anti-parallel regions of the magnetopause.

For this grant 150 Polar cusp events observed witin one hour of magnetic local time of noon have been analyzed. Reconnection locations at the Earth's magnetopause are determined by using the low-velocity cutoff method. While the previous general result was confirmed, the orbital bias of the Polar mission is such that many of the surveyed events occurred near equinox (i.e., small dipole tilt angle). Cusp equinox events, due to their symmetry, introduce an additional complication to predicting the location of the reconnection site. Several events that, according to the Maximum Magnetic shear model, would be associated with anti-parallel reconnection exhibit instead a component reconnection location. Since equinox events are known for anomalies as outlined in Trattner et al., [2016], this data set deserves further study.

 

Continuous or intermittent magnetic reconnection:

For the last science question (Q3: Is magnetic reconnection a continuous or intermittent process?), a methodology has been developed to calculate the time when an Earth magnetic field line is opened at the magnetopause by using ion dispersion distributions in the cusp regions. If reconnection is continuous, the "Time since reconnection" exhibits a continuous profile, while a pulsed event exhibits a stepped profile. A paper discussing examples for both cases was published in 2015. This methodology is now regularly used in all these cusp studies and more results based on this improvement in this diagnostic can be expected in the future.

The cusp data bases from the Polar and Cluster missions contain thousands of events. While most cusp events show distinctive cusp structures in the form of steps caused by either temporal or spatial variations of the reconnection rate or the reconnection location, there is also a set of single dispersion cases. For such events, the question arises whether these single dispersion cases represent smooth and continuous reconnection events at the magnetopause, or if they represent a single reconnection pulse with the reconnection process ceasing (i.e., the reconnection rate decreasing to zero) for extended periods of time. Applying the methodology developed under this grant, the "Time since reconnection" has been determined. It is shown that single dispersion events are continuous reconnection events with the reconnection location close to the equatorial region. An example of such a single dispersion event is shown below. The figures depict a single dispersion event observed by Polar/TIMAS, the magnetopause shear angle plot with the reconnection location, and the reconnection time plot.
